dc:description:
The relationship between *BOLA3* and primary mitochondrial disease was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of July 24, 2023. The *BOLA3* gene encodes bola family member 3, a mitochondrial iron-sulfur (Fe-S) cluster assembly factor involved in iron-sulfur cluster biogenesis. Iron-sulfur clusters are necessary for electron transport through oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) as well for other cellular proteins, including for normal maturation of lipoate-containing enzymes and for assembly of OXPHOS complexes.

The *BOLA3* gene was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive primary mitochondrial disease in 2011 (PMID: 21944046). While various names have been given to the constellation of features seen in those with *BOLA3*-related disease, pathogenic variants in this gene cause a primary mitochondrial disease. Therefore, the *BOLA3* phenotype has been lumped into one disease entity according to the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Framework.

Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. This curation included three variants from five individuals from three publications (PMIDs: 21944046, 22562699, 24334290). More cases are reported in the medical literature (PMIDs: 26741492, 30302924, 29353736, 29654549, 32742935, 35803560) but not included in this curation as the maximum case level score was reached. Affected individuals are variably affected although onset tends to be infantile and early death may occur. Most reported individuals have leukodystrophy and seizures, but additional clinical features include neurodegeneration, spasticity, contractures, lethargy, myoclonus, ataxia, choreoathetoid movements, irritability, intellectual disability, developmental delay, developmental regression, hypertrophic or dilated cardiomyopathy, feeding difficulty, failure to thrive, vomiting, diarrhea, hepatomegaly, respiratory insufficiency, and optic atrophy. Brain imaging has shown changes in white matter, midbrain, cerebral/cerebellar atrophy, and cervical spine. Lab abnormalities include lactic acidosis, elevated glucose, elevated plasma glycine, elevated tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle metabolites on urine organic acids, and decreased activity of 2-oxoacid dehydrogenases and the glycine cleavage enzyme. Muscle biopsies have shown variable decreased activities of OXPHOS complexes I, II, II + III, and IV (also decreased in fibroblasts) and decreased pyruvate dehydrogenase complex activity. Some individuals have normal OXPHOS complex activities. Variants reported include nonsense, missense, and frameshift.

Loss of function is the mechanism of disease. This gene-disease association is also supported by known biochemical function (PMID: 33340416).

In summary, there is definitive evidence to support this gene-disease relationship, including that more than three years have elapsed since the first proposal of the association. No convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the NICHD/NINDS U24 ClinGen Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel on July 24, 2023 (SOP Version 9).

evidence.dc:description: Transduction of fibroblast lines with retroviral vectors expressing the mitochondrial, but not the cytosolic isoform of NFU1 and with isoform 1, but not isoform 2 of BOLA3 restored both respiratory chain function and oxoacid dehydrogenase complexes’ function. Both play essential roles in the production of [Fe-S] centers for the normal maturation of lipoate-containing 2-oxoacid dehydrogenases, and for the assembly of the respiratory chain complexes.

Transduction of fibroblast lines with retroviral vectors expressing the mitochondrial, but not the cytosolic isoform of NFU1 and with isoform 1, but not isoform 2 of BOLA3 restored both respiratory chain function and oxoacid dehydrogenase complexes’ function. Both play essential roles in the production of [Fe-S] centers for the normal maturation of lipoate-containing 2-oxoacid dehydrogenases, and for the assembly of the respiratory chain complexes.

evidence.rdfs:label: Cameron_Family 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
This is a male with normal development until 4 months when he developed seizures as well as elevated levels of serum glycine (571 mM) and CSF glycine (28 mM). At 6 months, he was developmentally delayed and the frequency of seizures increased. Subsequently, he developed dilated cardiomyopathy and epileptic encephalopathy. He suffered from recurrent vomiting, progressive lethargy, tachypnea, diaphoresis, respiratory distress, and hepatomegaly. At 7 months, he became acidotic. His initial lactate level was 11.5 mM, but it increased to 19 mM in the course of few weeks. His CSF glycine levels rose to 1,039 mM, and his condition progressively deteriorated.
He died at 11 mo of age.

evidence.dc:description: Western blotting of lipoylated proteins in patient fibroblasts showed reduced lipoylated E2 subunits of pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-KGHD vs controls. Cultured skin fibroblasts had deficient pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme activity and normal respiratory chain enzyme activities.

Western blotting of lipoylated proteins in patient fibroblasts showed reduced lipoylated E2 subunits of pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-KGHD vs controls. Cultured skin fibroblasts had deficient pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme activity and normal respiratory chain enzyme activities.

evidence.rdfs:label: Baker_6
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This girl had normal development until 6 months of age, when development slowed with hypotonia and poor head control. At the age of 12 months, she had myoclonus and choreoathetoid movements. By 2 years, she had 7 to 10 words and walked independently, but had tonic clonic seizures controlled on a single anti-epileptic medication. Age 3 years, she was diagnosed with NKH. She had a developmental quotient of 43% at 3.5 years. From ages 3 to 8 years, she slowly developed spasticity and ataxia, lost her ability to walk, and became non-verbal. At 9 years of age, she developed recurrent status epilepticus, and severe deterioration after an apneic event with hypoglycemia. She had poor feeding resulting in severe malnutrition with loss of body weight over 1 year. Her worsening spasticity was accompanied by contractures. She died at the age of 11 years. MRI revealed mild cerebral and cerebellar atrophy, but no leukodystrophy.

evidence.dc:description: Cultured skin fibroblasts had deficient pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme activity and normal respiratory chain enzyme activities. In contrast, both the mitochondrial and cytosolic aconitase activities were normal.

Cultured skin fibroblasts had deficient pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme activity and normal respiratory chain enzyme activities. In contrast, both the mitochondrial and cytosolic aconitase activities were normal.

evidence.rdfs:label: Baker_5
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This child had normal birth and early development. This is the child of first cousin consanguineous Indian parents. At 8 months, there was regression of skills including loss of head control and inability to roll over. The child developed seizures, severe hypotonia and extrapyramidal signs, poor feeding and diarrhea, optic atrophy and vision loss. MRI revealed signal abnormalities involving the deep white matter and sparing the subcortical fibers. There was increased lactate on magnetic resonance spectroscopy. She died at 22 months after an acute febrile illness. Post-mortem examination revealed HCM with mitochondrial proliferation, and loss of all cellular material in the white matter. A previous sibling had died of a similar condition.

evidence.dc:description: 0.1 for other variant type + 0.4 (biochemical deficiency) + 0.4 (for rescue) = 1

Authors performed complementation experiments in patient fibroblasts to test for functional rescue of impaired enzyme activities. They expressed wildtype cDNA in patient and control fibroblasts using lentiviral mediated expression of the mitochondrial isoform of wildtype BOLA3 (isoform 1), which lead to an increase of both residual enzyme activities  - complex I from 32% to 82%. They also tested levels of lipoic acid in fibroblasts by immunoblotting that showed lower levels restored by wildtype cDNA. Immunohistochemical investigations of assembled complex II in patient fibroblasts by confocal microscopy demonstrated a clear reduction of succinate dehydrogenase, which was restored after expression of wildtype BOLA3.

evidence.rdfs:label: Haack_Proband 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This child had an early onset fatal course of the disease leading to death within the first year of life, including severe neonatal lactic acidosis, hypotonia and intractable cardiomyopathy. There were feeding difficulties, increased plasma lactate (7.7 mmol/L), and failure to thrive in first weeks of life, as well as progressive muscular hypotonia, respiratory insufficiency and increased severe lactic acidosis (32.6 mmol/L). There was also increased plasma glucose and glycine concentration and urinary analysis showed elevated succinate, fumarate, malate, aconitic acid, citric acid together with increased excretion of lactate and pyruvate. Skeletal muscle biopsy and patient fibroblasts showed a combined deficiency of respiratory chain complexes I (24% / 24%), II (5% /10%), and II+III (10% / 16%) with defect of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (10% / 7.6%). 2D BN/SDS-PAGE  showed clear decrease in complex I- containing supercomplexes. ECG showed hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Brain MRI (9 weeks old) showed delayed myelination, T2-weighted bifrontal and biparietal hyperintense lesions supra- and periventricular as well as in the midbrain in the formatio reticularis. There was rapid neurological deterioration with seizures, severe muscular hypotonia, persistent lactic acidosis and death due to multi organ failure at the age of 3 months.

evidence.dc:description: Western blotting of lipoylated proteins in patient fibroblasts showed reduced lipoylated E2 subunits of pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-KGHD vs controls.  Cultured skin fibroblasts had deficient pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme activity and normal respiratory chain enzyme activities. In contrast, both the mitochondrial and cytosolic aconitase activities were normal.

evidence.rdfs:label: Baker_4
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: This boy had normal birth and development to 6 months when he had regression in gross motor skills, hypotonia, and poor head control. He also had visual inattention as a result of optic atrophy, increased irritability, poor feeding, and episodes of spasticity and myoclonus without correlate on EEG, and without seizures. An ECG revealed mild left ventricular hypertrophy. MRI revealed signal abnormalities involving the deep white matter, optic nerve and cervical spine. He deteriorated precipitously and died at the age of 7 months.

evidence.dc:description: There are 9 genes in the same class with curations performed and gene-disease relationships confirmed.
